title: Review: Waskerley Way – Haunted Tors
content:
Photo: Chris Trew

My first live experience of Waskerley Way is a memory that I will undoubtedly take with me to the grave.

Crammed into a claustrophobic pub in Newcastle, surrounded by beer guzzling geordies, the solo performance of a slightly bewildered multi-instrumentalist perched nervously overly a decidedly understated HP laptop couldn’t have been more of a shock to the system for the majority. Without intending to offend the acts who preceded Waskerley Way, they were noticeably more testosterone driven, and I’m sure they would agree, more brit-pop influenced than the glo-gaze vibe of Waskerley, especially when armed with a clarinet. Yet what made this performance so special, was that it worked, and left sizable portions of the crowd completely awestruck.

As a musician, Michael Bridgewater is somewhat of an outsider amongst the tightly packed Newcastle scene. That’s not to say he’s an unmentionable outcast, but his ability to gather inspirations from further afield has allowed him to craft his own unique sound. New release Haunted Tors is a glistening shoegaze affair, and certainly his strongest outing to date, bringing together all the various concepts he’s played with since the inception of Waskerley Way.

The latter half of the album opener showcases Bridgewater at his utmost invigorating, diving mercilessly into a thoroughly immersing guitar riff and reverb drenched vocals. At times Waskerley’s vocals are vaguely reminiscent of a young Jarvis Cocker, with their unflappable subtly and ever-so-charming undertones; almost like the kind of guy you’d be more than happy to introduce your mum to.


Personal highlight is the 80’s throwback of Thinges To Come, a no-frills attached glo-fi number, demonstrating just how far this young artist has come in a relatively short space of time. As I so often find, it’s all too easy to ignore what’s on your doorstep, however in the case of Waskerley Way, he’s well and truly found a place in my heart.

Haunter Tors is out now via Waskerley Way’s bandcamp.
